natural problem:
The polynomial
$$g(x) = x^3-14x^2+18x+72$$has one integer root. What is it?
natural solution: By the Integer Root Theorem, any integer root must be a divisor of the constant term -- thus, in this case, a (positive or negative) divisor of $72$.

However, this leaves quite a lot of candidates: $$\pm 1,\ \pm 2,\ \pm 3,\ \pm 4,\ \pm 6,\ \pm 8,\ \pm 9,\ \pm 12,\ \pm 18,\ \pm 24,\ \pm 36,\ \pm 72.$$To narrow our choices, we define another polynomial.
Note that $g(1) = 77.$  Then by the Factor Theorem, $g(x) - 77$ is divisible by $x - 1.$  In other words, $$g(x) = (x-1)q(x) + 77$$for some polynomial $q(x)$.
Thus if we define $h(x) = g(x+1)$, then we have $$h(x) = xq(x+1) + 77,$$so $h(x)$ has a constant term of $77$.

Thus any integer root of $h(x)$ is a divisor of $77$; the possibilities are $$-77,\ -11,\ -7,\ -1,\ 1,\ 7,\ 11,\ 77.$$This is useful because, if $x$ is a root of $g(x)$, then $h(x-1)=g(x)=0$, so $x-1$ must appear in the list of roots of $h(x)$.

In particular, $x$ must be $1$ more than a root of $h(x)$, which gives the possibilities $$-76,\ -10,\ -6,\ 0,\ 2,\ 8,\ 12,\ 78.$$Of these, only $-6$, $2$, $8$, and $12$ were candidates in our original list.
Testing them one by one, we find that $x=\boxed{12}$ is the only integer root of $g(x)$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 - 14 * x powr 2 + 18 * x + 72"
and h1 : "\<exists> a \<in> Int. g a = 0"
shows  "\<exists> a \<in> Int. a = 12"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The polynomial
$$g(x) = x^3-14x^2+18x+72$$has one integer root. What is it? The final Answer is 12
 ### Proof
 By the Integer Root Theorem, any integer root must be a divisor of the constant term -- thus, in this case, a (positive or negative) divisor of $72$.
 However, this leaves quite a lot of candidates: $$\pm 1,\ \pm 2,\ \pm 3,\ \pm 4,\ \pm 6,\ \pm 8,\ \pm 9,\ \pm 12,\ \pm 18,\ \pm 24,\ \pm 36,\ \pm 72.$$To narrow our choices, we define another polynomial.

 Thus any integer root of $h(x)$ is a divisor of $77$; the possibilities are $$-77,\ -11,\ -7,\ -1,\ 1,\ 7,\ 11,\ 77.$$This is useful because, if $x$ is a root of $g(x)$, then $h(x-1)=g(x)=0$, so $x-1$ must appear in the list of roots of $h(x)$.
 In particular, $x$ must be $1$ more than a root of $h(x)$, which gives the possibilities $$-76,\ -10,\ -6,\ 0,\ 2,\ 8,\ 12,\ 78.$$Of these, only $-6$, $2$, $8$, and $12$ were candidates in our original list.
 Testing them one by one, we find that $x=\boxed{12}$ is the only integer root of $g(x)$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 - 14 * x powr 2 + 18 * x + 72"
and h1 : "\<exists> a \<in> Int. g a = 0"
shows  "\<exists> a \<in> Int. a = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find an integer value for $x$ that satisfies the equation $x^3 - 14x^2 + 18x + 72 = 0$. The final answer is $12$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 - 14 * x powr 2 + 18 * x + 72"
and h1 : "\<exists> z \<in> \<int>. poly (map_poly of_real (Poly [72, 18, -14, 1])) z = 0"
shows  "poly (map_poly of_real (Poly [72, 18, -14, 1])) 12 = 0"
a_1.formal solution:

 Testing them one by one, we find that $x=\boxed{12}$ is the only integer root of $g(x)$.
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 - 14 * x powr 2 + 18 * x + 72"
and h1 : "\<exists> z \<in> \<int>. poly (map_poly of_real (Poly [72, 18, -14, 1])) z = 0"
shows  "poly (map_poly of_real (Poly [72, 18, -14, 1])) 12 = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find an integer root of the cubic equation $x^3 - 14x^2 + 18x + 72 = 0$. The final answer is $12$.

fixes x :: int and g :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 - 14 * x powr 2 + 18 * x + 72"

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 - 14 * x powr 2 + 18 * x + 72"
and h1 : "is_int (g x)"
shows  "x = 12"

theorem
fixes x :: real and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 - 14 * x powr 2 + 18 * x + 72"
and h1 : "is_int (g x)"
shows  "x = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Find the value of $x$ that makes $x^3 - 14x^2 + 18x + 72$ an integer. The final answer is $12$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"

and h1 : "\<exists> x::int. poly [1, -14, 18, 72] x = 0"
shows  "\<exists> x::int. poly [1, -14, 18, 72] x = 0 \<and> x = 12"

theorem
fixes x :: real and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 - 14 * x powr 2 + 18 * x + 72"
and h1 : "\<exists> x::int. poly [1, -14, 18, 72] x = 0"
shows  "\<exists> x::int. poly [1, -14, 18, 72] x = 0 \<and> x = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find an integer root of the polynomial $x^3 - 14x^2 + 18x + 72$. The solution is $x = 12$.

fixes x :: real and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 - 14 * x powr 2 + 18 * x + 72"
and h1 : "\<exists> x :: int. g x = 0"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer

fixes x :: real and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 - 14 * x powr 2 + 18 * x + 72"
and h1 : "\<exists> z :: int. poly (map_poly of_int (coeffs g)) z = 0"
shows  "z = 12"

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 - 14 * x powr 2 + 18 * x + 72"
and h1 : "\<exists> n :: int. g n = 0"
shows  "THE n. g n = 0 = 12"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 *)

theorem
fixes x g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. g x = x powr 3 - 14 * x powr 2 + 18 * x + 72"
and h1 : "\<exists> n :: int. g n = 0"
shows  "THE n. g n = 0 = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: The function $g(x) = x^3 - 14x^2 + 18x + 72$ has an integer root. Find this root. The final answer is $12$.
